turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: I'm so frustrated! We've had a huge spike in AR denials this month, and I can't figure out why. It's driving me crazy!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your frustration. A spike in AR denials can be very disruptive. To help me investigate, could you tell me which denial codes are occurring most frequently?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, let me pull up the report... It looks like we're seeing a lot of CO-97 and 276.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: CO-97 indicates the benefit for this service is included in the payment/allowance for another service or procedure that has already been adjudicated. 276 indicates missing/incomplete/invalid diagnosis or condition. Are these denials concentrated with a specific payer or provider?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Mostly with United Healthcare, and it seems to be across multiple providers in our group. What's the best way to tackle these, especially the CO-97 denials? They seem so vague.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: For the CO-97 denials, you'll want to carefully review the patient's claims history to identify potentially bundled services. Verify that all coding modifiers are appropriate and accurately reflect the services performed. Sometimes a simple coding error can cause this type of denial. I suggest reviewing UHC's bundling guidelines on their website.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I will look into that. But if we're coding everything correctly, and UHC is still denying, what recourse do we have? I feel like we are constantly fighting with them over bundled services.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: If you believe the services were appropriately coded and not truly bundled, you should file an appeal with United Healthcare. Be sure to include supporting documentation, such as the patient's medical records and a detailed explanation of why you believe the services are separately billable. Track all your appeals carefully. Unfortunately, appealing denials is sometimes necessary, and persistence is key.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Alright, thanks for the advice. It's a starting point, at least. I appreciate it.
